docblock.description: Each application is able to create its front controller easily creating an App object which can then be "run".
docblock.long-description:
The root namespace of the application must be passed or the router will not be able to find your application specific code.

Example:

The following code should be in the index.php within your webroot for a site/application

  // Include the file with the App class.
  // Once the App object is constructed all your classes can be found and
  //   included by the autoloader.
  require_once("../../lolmvc/app.php");

  // Create a new App with the name of the app.
  // The name of the app should be the same as the name of the folder and
  //   namespace for your app.
  $skel = new \Lolmvc\App('skel');

  // Optional configuration can be done here.  See function defenitions
  //   below for the possibilities.

  // Siginal the app to execute
  $skel->run();

docblock.description: The name of the app, should be the same as the app's namespace
Constructor
Loads a local configuration file for the app.
docblock.long-description: The format for the file is identical to the framework level configuration but exists in the root of the application. See the local configuration for the Skel example app for more information.

docblock.description: Called after all settings are complete and triggers the app to actually "run".
docblock.long-description: This means that the router created and generates the controller which allows us to trigger the display of the rendered webpage.

docblock.description: Called as the first step of running the app.
docblock.long-description: Helper function that sets the app state now that all configuration values have been imported.

docblock.description: Abstract class that provides the methods and properties that all controllers will need to inherit.
docblock.long-description: Each app should utilize an abstract base controller class that extends this one. Such an app level base controller can encapsulate all the application specific properties and methods that you want available to all controllers within your app.

docblock.description: Autoloader implements the PHP Framework Interoperability Group's PHP Standards Recommendation for autoloading classes.
docblock.long-description:
http://github.com/php-fig/fig-standards/blob/master/accepted/PSR-0.md

// Example which loads classes for the Exegesis annotation parser.
<pre><code>    $classLoader = new Autoloader('MattRWallace', ['vendor/matt/src','/vendor/matt']);
$classLoader->register();
</code></pre>

docblock.description: Determines which controller is requested in the URI and creates an instance of it.
docblock.long-description:
The remainder of the URI (Action and params) are passed to the controller's constructor so that the constructor can determine the appropriate actions.

Example:

The following code is how the App object handles routing and status 404 responses.

try {
   $router = new \Lolmvc\Service\Router($_SERVER['REQUEST_URI'], 'Skel');
} catch (\Lolmvc\Service\PageNotFoundException $e) {
   // get the error404 classname
   if (CUSTOM_404)
      $error404namespace = $appname;
   else
      $error404namespace = "lolmvc";

   $request = "error404";
   $message = $e->getMessage();
   if (!empty($message))
      $request .= "/$message/";
   $router = new
   \Lolmvc\Service\Route($request, $error404namespace);
}

docblock.description: A templating engine that extends the BaseView.
docblock.long-description:
Variables may to be added to the view, the names of the view template and the layout template should be set the same way that other variables are. The predetermined names for these settings are 'viewName' and 'layoutName'.

TODO: The classname was an application specific need in the original application. The requirement to pass it to the constructor should be replaced by setting it as a normal view variable in the app's controller.

Example:

$this->view = new \Lolmvc\Service\Template('mysite', $classShortName);
$this->view->pageTitle   = "My home page";
$this->view->pageHeading = "This is my home page";
$template->renderPage();

TODO: Add information about how to structure template file locations and why app name is required.

TODO: Explain how multiple JavaScript files are handled

Note: Original logic derived from Chad Emrys Minick's "Simple PHP template engine"

docblock.description: Array containing "name" => value pairs for variables that will be used by the views/layouts.
The name of the view template
The name of the layout template
The name of the controller
The name of the application
Constructor
Allows setting of view variable values.
docblock.long-description:
Example:

To set a value for a view variable named 'key' to the value 'value' ...

$template->key = $value;

docblock.description: Allows retrieving of view variable values.
docblock.long-description:
Example:

To print the value of a previously set view variable named 'key' ...

echo $template->key;

docblock.description: Renders and displays the HTML using the privided templates and the variables that have been added to the templating engine.
